source.name: City of Portland Bureau of Planning and Sustainability
source.notes: Based on official Portland BPS recycling and composting guidelines. Glass has separate bin. Pizza boxes go in compost. Weekly compost, bi-weekly garbage.

materials.name: Plastic bottles and jugs
notes: Caps are OK if screwed back on the bottle
Must be rigid plastic, not film
commonMistakes: Don't include bottles with liquid still in them
Don't crush — caps must be screwed on

materials.name: Plastic tubs and buckets
instructions: Must be at least 2" x 2" in size
notes: Portland requires rigid plastic containers be at least 2" x 2"
Lids smaller than 2" x 2" go in garbage
commonMistakes: Don't include plastic lids smaller than 2" x 2"
Don't include clamshell/takeout containers

materials.name: Aluminum cans
notes: Aluminum is infinitely recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food residue

materials.name: Steel / tin food cans
notes: Labels are removed during recycling process
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food still in them

materials.name: Empty paint cans
instructions: Must be COMPLETELY empty and dry
Remove lid and place both in BLUE recycling bin
notes: Portland-specific: empty paint cans are accepted in blue bin
Cans with wet paint are hazardous waste
commonMistakes: Don't recycle cans with paint still in them — that's hazardous waste
Latex paint can be dried out with kitty litter first

materials.name: Aerosol cans (empty)
notes: Non-empty aerosol cans are hazardous waste
commonMistakes: Don't recycle if still pressurized or has product inside

materials.name: Scrap metal (small)
instructions: Must be under 18 inches in any dimension
notes: Portland accepts small scrap metal in curbside recycling
Larger scrap metal should go to a metal recycler
commonMistakes: Don't include pieces over 18" or over 10 lbs
Don't include electronics or appliances

materials.name: Cardboard
instructions: Place in or beside BLUE recycling bin
notes: Must be clean and dry
Food-soiled cardboard goes in green compost bin
commonMistakes: Don't include pizza boxes — those go in GREEN compost bin
Don't include wet or food-soiled cardboard

materials.name: Paper and newspapers
notes: All clean paper goes in blue bin
commonMistakes: Don't include food-soiled paper — that goes in green compost
Don't bag paper in plastic bags

materials.name: Magazines and catalogs
notes: Glossy paper is accepted
commonMistakes: Don't bag in plastic

materials.name: Junk mail and envelopes
instructions: Window envelopes OK — no need to remove plastic window
notes: All clean mail and envelopes accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include plastic-padded mailers

materials.name: Cereal boxes / paperboard
instructions: Flatten and place in BLUE recycling bin
notes: Clean paperboard boxes go in blue bin
commonMistakes: Don't include frozen food boxes — those go in garbage
Remove plastic liners/bags inside

materials.name: Food and beverage cartons
notes: Includes gable-top and aseptic (shelf-stable) cartons
commonMistakes: Must be empty and dry before recycling

materials.name: Aluminum foil
instructions: Ball up to at least golf-ball size
notes: Must be clean — food-soiled foil goes in garbage
commonMistakes: Don't recycle heavily soiled foil

materials.name: Books
instructions: If damaged, place in BLUE recycling bin
notes: Donating is always better than recycling
commonMistakes: Don't throw usable books in trash

materials.name: Shredded paper
instructions: Place in a paper bag and staple shut
Place bagged shredded paper in BLUE recycling bin
notes: Must be bagged in paper to prevent litter
commonMistakes: Don't put loose shredded paper in blue bin
Don't use plastic bags

materials.name: Glass bottles and jars
instructions: Remove metal lids (recycle lids in blue bin)
Place in SEPARATE GLASS-ONLY bin — NOT the blue recycling bin
notes: PORTLAND-SPECIFIC: Glass has its own dedicated bin, separate from the blue recycling bin
Your hauler provides a glass-only bin
All colors of glass accepted
commonMistakes: Do NOT put glass in the blue recycling bin — it has its own separate bin
Don't include window glass, mirrors, ceramics, or drinking glasses
Don't include broken glass — wrap in newspaper and put in garbage

materials.name: Food waste (all types)
instructions: Place ALL food waste in GREEN compost bin
All food accepted: meat, dairy, bones, fish, fruit, vegetables, grains — everything
notes: Portland has comprehensive food composting
Weekly green bin collection
commonMistakes: Don't put food in garbage — it belongs in green compost bin
Don't include liquids or grease

materials.name: Fruit and fruit scraps
notes: All fruit and fruit scraps accepted
commonMistakes: Don't put in garbage

materials.name: Vegetables and vegetable scraps
notes: All vegetables accepted including rinds, peels, and cores
commonMistakes: Don't put in garbage

materials.name: Meat, poultry, and fish
instructions: Includes raw and cooked meat, skin, fat, and gristle
notes: Portland's industrial composting handles all meat safely
Wrap in newspaper or place in paper bag to reduce odor
commonMistakes: Don't put in garbage
Don't include packaging — only the food

materials.name: Bones
notes: Portland's commercial composting processes bones
commonMistakes: Don't put in garbage

materials.name: Dairy products
instructions: Rinse and recycle the container separately
notes: All dairy products accepted in green bin
commonMistakes: Don't put dairy in garbage
Recycle the container in blue bin after rinsing

materials.name: Bread, pasta, and rice
notes: All grain-based foods accepted
commonMistakes: Don't put in garbage

materials.name: Eggs and eggshells
notes: Eggshells add calcium to compost
commonMistakes: Don't put in garbage

materials.name: Coffee grounds and paper filters
instructions: Place paper filter and grounds directly in GREEN compost bin
notes: Paper coffee filters are accepted
No need to separate grounds from paper filter
commonMistakes: Don't include plastic K-cups or pods — those go in garbage

materials.name: Tea bags
notes: Most tea bags are paper and compostable
Remove staples if present
commonMistakes: Check that the bag is paper, not nylon mesh — nylon goes in garbage

materials.name: Yard waste — leaves, grass, weeds
notes: Yard waste and food waste share the green bin in Portland
commonMistakes: Don't bag in plastic — use paper yard waste bags or put loose in bin
Don't include treated or painted wood

materials.name: Flowers and houseplants
instructions: Remove from pot (pot goes in garbage unless recyclable)
Place plant material in GREEN compost bin
notes: All plant material is compostable
commonMistakes: Don't include the pot or wire/plastic supports

materials.name: Small branches and prunings
instructions: Branches must be under 4 inches in diameter
notes: Portland limit: branches under 4" diameter and 36" length
Larger branches require yard debris bundling or drop-off
commonMistakes: Don't include branches over 4" diameter or 36" long

materials.name: Pizza boxes
instructions: Place in GREEN compost bin — NOT the blue recycling bin
Even greasy/food-soiled pizza boxes go in green
notes: PORTLAND-SPECIFIC: Pizza boxes go in compost, not recycling
This is different from many other cities
commonMistakes: Do NOT put pizza boxes in the blue recycling bin
Do NOT put in garbage

materials.name: Food-soiled napkins and paper towels
instructions: Place food-soiled napkins and paper towels in GREEN compost bin
notes: Must be food-soiled to go in green bin
Clean napkins/paper towels also accepted in green bin
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling bin
Don't put in garbage if food-soiled

materials.name: Condiments and sauces (food portion)
instructions: Scrape food into GREEN compost bin
Rinse the container and recycle in BLUE bin
notes: Separate food from container
commonMistakes: Don't recycle containers with food still in them

materials.name: Snacks and candy (food portion)
notes: Separate food from wrapper
commonMistakes: Don't put wrappers in compost

materials.name: Disposable coffee cups
instructions: Place in GARBAGE — NOT recyclable or compostable in Portland
Plastic lids go in garbage too
notes: PORTLAND-SPECIFIC: Coffee cups are NOT accepted in blue bin OR green bin
The plastic/wax lining makes them non-recyclable and non-compostable
This is different from Seattle where compostable cups are accepted
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling bin
Don't put in green compost bin
Consider bringing a reusable cup

materials.name: Takeout containers
instructions: Not accepted in blue recycling or green compost
notes: Includes plastic clamshells, black plastic containers, and paper takeout boxes
Even if marked 'recyclable' — not accepted in Portland curbside
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue bin even if it has a recycling symbol
Don't put in green compost bin

materials.name: Frozen food boxes
notes: Frozen food boxes have a special moisture-resistant coating that prevents recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling bin — the coating prevents recycling

materials.name: Plastic bags and film
instructions: Do NOT put in blue recycling bin — bags jam machinery
Take clean bags to grocery store drop-off bins
notes: Many Portland grocery stores accept clean plastic bags for recycling
Fred Meyer, Safeway, and Target have drop-off bins
commonMistakes: Never bag recyclables in plastic bags
Never put bags in the blue bin

materials.name: Plastic lids (loose)
instructions: If a cap screws onto a bottle, screw it on and recycle together
notes: Loose plastic lids under 2" x 2" are too small for Portland recycling
Bottle caps are OK if screwed onto the bottle
commonMistakes: Don't put loose plastic lids in blue bin

materials.name: Plastic cutlery and straws
notes: Too small and contaminated for recycling
Consider reusable alternatives
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling bin
Even if marked 'compostable' — still goes in garbage in Portland

materials.name: Plastic-padded mailers
notes: The combination of plastic and paper/bubble wrap makes these non-recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling bin

materials.name: Wax-coated paper and containers
instructions: Not accepted in blue recycling or green compost
notes: PORTLAND-SPECIFIC: Wax-coated items are NOT accepted in recycling OR compost
This includes wax paper, waxed cardboard, and wax-coated cups
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue bin — wax contaminates paper recycling
Don't put in green compost bin

materials.name: Styrofoam / polystyrene
notes: Styrofoam cannot be recycled in Portland's curbside program
Large amounts of packing styrofoam can go to Metro transfer stations
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling bin
Don't put in green compost bin

materials.name: Chip bags and snack pouches
notes: The metallic interior cannot be separated for recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Candy wrappers
notes: Too small and mixed materials
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling or compost

materials.name: Diapers
notes: Not compostable or recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put in green compost bin

materials.name: Thermal receipts
instructions: Thermal paper contains BPA; not recyclable
notes: Thermal receipts contaminate paper recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling bin

materials.name: Pet waste
notes: Portland does not accept pet waste in green compost bin
commonMistakes: Don't put in green compost bin

materials.name: Bubble wrap and air pillows
instructions: Or deflate and take to store drop-off with plastic bags
notes: Plastic film jams recycling machinery
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling bin

materials.name: "Compostable" containers and serviceware
instructions: Place in GARBAGE — NOT accepted in Portland's green compost bin
The ONLY exception: BPI-certified compostable bags can line your kitchen pail
notes: PORTLAND-SPECIFIC: 'Compostable' containers are NOT accepted in the green bin
Portland's composting facility does not process these
Only BPI-certified compostable bags (for lining your collection pail) are allowed
commonMistakes: Don't put in green compost bin even if labeled 'compostable'
Don't put in blue recycling bin

materials.name: Paper plates
instructions: Not accepted in Portland's green compost or blue recycling
notes: PORTLAND-SPECIFIC: Paper plates are NOT accepted in the green compost bin
This differs from some other cities
commonMistakes: Don't put in green compost bin
Don't put in blue recycling bin

materials.name: Plastic film and wrap
instructions: Or take clean, dry film to grocery store drop-off
notes: Plastic film jams recycling machinery
Store drop-off is the better option for clean film
commonMistakes: Never put in blue recycling bin

materials.name: Toothbrush
notes: Consider a bamboo toothbrush as an alternative
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Paper towels (clean)
instructions: Clean paper towels go in GARBAGE
Food-soiled paper towels go in GREEN compost bin
notes: Portland does not accept clean paper towels in blue recycling
If soiled with food, switch to green compost bin
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling bin
Food-soiled paper towels go in green compost, not garbage
examples: Paper towel used for water spill

materials.name: Batteries
instructions: Take to a hazardous waste drop-off or participating retailer
Tape terminals of lithium and 9-volt batteries to prevent fires
notes: Batteries cause fires in garbage trucks and recycling facilities
Many stores accept batteries: Home Depot, Batteries Plus, Best Buy
commonMistakes: Don't put in garbage or blue recycling bin

materials.name: Paint (liquid)
instructions: Latex paint: dry out with kitty litter or paint hardener, then garbage
Oil-based paint, stain, thinner: take to Metro hazardous waste facility
PaintCare drop-off locations accept all paint for free
notes: Portland has PaintCare drop-off sites at many retail stores
Metro South or Metro Central transfer stations accept hazardous waste
commonMistakes: Don't pour paint down the drain
Empty dry paint cans go in blue recycling bin

materials.name: Motor oil
instructions: Take to auto parts store or Metro transfer station
notes: Most auto parts stores (AutoZone, O'Reilly) accept for free
commonMistakes: Don't pour down drain or on ground

materials.name: Propane tanks
notes: Pressurized containers are dangerous in garbage and recycling
commonMistakes: Never puncture
Don't put in garbage or blue bin

materials.name: Light bulbs
instructions: CFL and fluorescent: take to Home Depot, IKEA, or Metro transfer station
LED and incandescent: wrap carefully and place in garbage
notes: CFL and fluorescent bulbs contain mercury
Home Depot accepts CFL bulbs at no charge
commonMistakes: Don't put CFL or fluorescent bulbs in garbage

materials.name: Fluorescent tubes
instructions: Take to Metro transfer station or Home Depot/IKEA
notes: Free drop-off at participating retailers
commonMistakes: Don't break — mercury vapor is dangerous
Don't put in garbage

materials.name: Medications
instructions: Take to a pharmacy with a drug take-back kiosk
Many Walgreens and Fred Meyer pharmacies in Portland participate
notes: Oregon has a statewide drug take-back program
commonMistakes: Don't flush medications
Don't pour liquid meds down drain

materials.name: Needles and sharps
instructions: Place in an approved sharps container
Take to pharmacy or Metro transfer station
Never put loose in garbage or recycling
notes: Free sharps containers available at some Portland pharmacies
commonMistakes: Never put loose sharps in any bin

materials.name: Household chemicals and cleaners
instructions: Take to Metro hazardous waste facility
Metro South: 2001 Washington St, Oregon City
notes: Never mix chemicals
Metro accepts hazardous waste from Portland residents
commonMistakes: Don't pour down drain
Don't put in garbage

materials.name: Electronics / E-waste
instructions: Take to Free Geek, Best Buy, or Metro transfer station
Oregon E-Cycles program accepts TVs, computers, and monitors for free
notes: Oregon law prohibits e-waste in the garbage
Free Geek (1731 SE 10th Ave) refurbishes and recycles electronics
commonMistakes: Don't put in garbage or recycling
Wipe personal data first

materials.name: Smartphone / phone
instructions: Factory reset and remove SIM card
Take to Best Buy, Free Geek, or carrier store
notes: Oregon law prohibits e-waste in garbage
commonMistakes: Don't forget to wipe data and remove SIM

materials.name: Chargers and cables
instructions: Take to Best Buy or Free Geek
Don't put in blue recycling bin
notes: Cables tangle in recycling machinery
commonMistakes: Never put in curbside recycling

materials.name: Clothing and textiles
instructions: Donate usable clothing to Goodwill, Salvation Army, or Community Warehouse
Worn-out textiles: take to textile recycling (e.g., Nike Grind, Goodwill)
notes: Portland has many donation and textile recycling options
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling or green compost bin

materials.name: Mattress
instructions: Take to Metro Central or Metro South transfer station
Or schedule bulky waste pickup with your hauler
Some charities accept mattresses in good condition
notes: Fee may apply at transfer station
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb without scheduling pickup

materials.name: Tires
instructions: Take to tire retailer or Metro transfer station
Most shops accept old tires when you buy new ones
notes: Fee may apply
commonMistakes: Don't dump illegally

materials.name: Cooking oil and grease
instructions: Small amounts: absorb with paper towels and compost the towels
notes: Never pour down the drain — causes sewer clogs
Liquid grease is NOT accepted in the green compost bin
commonMistakes: Don't pour down sink or drain
Don't pour liquid grease into green bin

materials.name: Appliances
instructions: Large appliances: schedule pickup with hauler or take to Metro transfer station
Small appliances: take to Free Geek or Goodwill
Working appliances: donate to Community Warehouse
notes: Refrigerant-containing appliances (fridges, ACs) require special handling
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb without scheduling

materials.name: Beverages / drinks (leftover liquid)
instructions: Pour leftover liquid down drain or in green compost bin
Recycle the container in appropriate bin (blue bin or glass bin)
notes: Focus on recycling the container properly
commonMistakes: Empty containers before recycling

materials.name: Fast food wrappers
instructions: Clean paper wrappers with no food residue: BLUE recycling bin
notes: If in doubt about soiling, put in green compost
commonMistakes: Don't put greasy wrappers in blue recycling

materials.name: Aluminum pie pans and trays
notes: Must be clean — heavily soiled ones go in garbage
commonMistakes: Don't recycle if heavily soiled with baked-on food

recycle: Office paper, newspapers, magazines, catalogs, mail
Plastic bottles, jugs, tubs, and buckets (min 2" x 2")
Metal food cans, empty paint cans, empty aerosol cans
Food and beverage cartons (empty and dry)
GLASS: Separate glass-only bin (NOT blue bin)
compost: ALL food waste: meat, poultry, fish, dairy, bones, eggs, fruit, vegetables, bread, pasta, rice
Yard waste: leaves, grass, weeds, flowers, small branches (under 4"/36")
Paper coffee filters and tea bags
trash: Plastic bags and film (or store drop-off)

recycle: Glass in blue bin (glass has its own SEPARATE bin)

tips: GLASS goes in a SEPARATE glass-only bin — NOT the blue recycling bin
Pizza boxes go in the GREEN compost bin, not recycling
Coffee cups are NOT recyclable or compostable in Portland — they go in garbage
ALL food waste goes in green compost: meat, dairy, bones, fish — everything
"Compostable" containers are NOT accepted in green bin (only BPI bags for pail liners)
Garbage is collected BI-WEEKLY; compost and recycling are collected WEEKLY
Scrap metal under 18" and 10 lbs is accepted in the blue bin
Empty paint cans go in blue recycling bin

locations.name: Metro Central Transfer Station
locations.notes: Metro accepts hazardous waste from Portland area residents

locations.name: Free Geek
locations.notes: Accepts and refurbishes electronics; free drop-off
